subject: OT: Request for example -- boolean parameters
msgSnippet: Hello, everyone. In the midst of my current writing project I am describing replacing difficult-to-understand parameters with easier-to-understand ones. My
messageBody:
Hello, everyone.

In the midst of my current writing project I am describing replacing difficult-to-understand parameters with easier-to-understand ones. My particular example is boolean flags: in a positional-parameter language like Java, C or Ruby, it's virtually impossible to know just by looking at a method call what "true" or "false" mean, especially in a method that has several such flags in the same parameter list.

What I'd love is a real-life example of this, preferably from a well-known library. If anyone has, by chance, come across one of these monsters, I'd appreciate a reference.

In other words, a method like doIt(myObject, anotherObject, true, false, true, true);

What the hell does true, false, true, true mean?!

BTW: I'd appreciate a CC: to me directly by e-mail, especially from the XP mailing list, since I can't keep up with the traffic on that list.

Thanks a bunch everyone!


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
telephone: +1 416 791-8603
